newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Mir crew to start training soon for risky repairs.
newsitem.headline: Mir crew to start training soon for risky repairs.

text.p: The situation on the damaged space station Mir was "completely" under control on Saturday and the crew were told they would start training soon for difficult repair work, a Russian official said.

The American and two Russians on Mir, which collided with a cargo craft on Wednesday, were due to check how the station's batteries were charging and try to increase their oxygen supply before beginning their practice exercises.
"The situation on Mir is completely under the control of mission control and the crew," said Vladimir Solovyov, who is responsible for flight coordination at Korolyov mission control near Moscow.

He told reporters that 30 to 40 percent of Mir's electric power potential had been lost in the collision and added: "We plan that the crew will begin the training (to restore the power supply) on Monday."
Commander Vasily Tsibliyev, 43, flight engineer Alexander Lazutkin, 39, and American physicist Michael Foale, 40, enjoyed a good night's sleep and were relaxing on Saturday morning.

"We are well but I did not sleep for two nights after the collision. The first time I had a good night's sleep was last night," Tsibliyev told mission control during a radio conversation which reporters were able to listen to.
But he had some doubts about the risky repairs that lie ahead after the worst accident of Mir's 11 years in space.
"I have never done this kind of work. Without training, it will not be possible to do this job," Tsibliyev said.
Solovyov said: "We will help you do all the jobs".
The two Russians will don spacesuits to enter the Spektr scientific module, holed by a cargo craft during docking manoeuvres, while Foale sits in the escape capsule for safety.
They will have to install a modified hatch in Spektr's doorway so that cables can be connected to tap electricity from the module's solar arrays.
According to NASA officials, if the hatch to Spektr cannot be resealed, the crew will have to abandon ship.
Solovyov said a cargo craft would be launched on July 5 to take equipment to Mir. He expected the repairs to be done between July 10 and 14.
One piece of good news for Foale was that his wife was being allowed to send him a small package with personal effects, photos and toiletries.
He lost his toothbrush in the collision but another one had already been found for him in Mir's supplies, Solovyov said.
Mission control told the crew on Friday to relax and rest, but also set them some chores for Saturday and Sunday to try to improve the environment on Mir.

These included checking Mir's batteries are charging -- Wednesday's collision robbed it of its most efficient batteries -- and turning on equipment that produces oxygen automatically. They also hoped to reduce humidity on Mir.
Additional systems are being activated as Mir's batteries charge, including the station's toilet.
"As Mike (Foale) said, that was a great relief," Frank Culbertson, who oversees NASA's missions to Mir, told reporters at Cape Canaveral in Florida.
